NewsLines.HeadLine: Federer, Roddick reach second round at Toronto tennis event

DataContent.p: Andy Roddick kept pace with top seed Roger Federer, easily advancing to the second round of the 2.5- million-dollar ATP Masters Series as opponent Julien Benneteau suffered a mid-match injury.
Roddick, the Toronto defending champ and winner of a second straight title at the weekend in Indianapolis, advanced 6-4, 6-2 against the hampered Frenchman.
Benneteau, ranked 76th, gave Roddick a battle in the opening set, but strained his neck as he stretched for a return in the fourth game of the second.
"It's unfortunate to win this way, but you take what you can get," said the second-seeded American, who won his 50th match of the season. "The first set was high-level.
"He has some weapons, but once he hurt his neck he went downhill."
World number one Federer completed a match he had begun 18 hours before on the previous evening, ousting Moroccan Hicham Arazi 6-3, 7-5.

Federer next faces a second-round contest with Swede Robin Soderling. Like the rest of Thursday's winners, he will play a third-round contest only hours later as the tournament, gets back on schedule after Tuesday's rain delay.
"I'm very happy to have played so well, it's never easy with the rain," said the Swiss, winner of 26 of his last 27 matches.
"I'm ready for the next round, I'm very happy to be through."
Federer won his 52nd victory of the season, lifting the first set quickly on Tuesday evening and finishing the job Wednesday.
"I was in a good position overnight and that makes it much easier.
"I was happy to be up a set. I didn't know if we were going to play last night. But I was glad to get that set in before the rain."
Federer is making his summer hardcourt debut, with challenges awaiting next week at a Masters event in Cincinnati followed by the Athens Olympics and US Open beginning in a month.
Three Argentine seeds crashed out at the first hurdle, with Peru's Luis Horna going through as number three Guillermo Coria quit trailing 5-1 with a right shoulder problem.
Russian Mikhail Youzhny recovered in the final set to overhaul David Nalbandian, seeded sixth, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4.
Australian newcomer Todd Reid scalped Roland Garros champion Gaston Gaudio 7-6 (7/2), 5-7, 6-3.
Fellow Aussie ninth seed Lleyton Hewitt came good after a torrid first set from Spanish teenager Rafael Nadal, producing a patented 1-6, 6-4, 6-2 fight-back victory.
Fourth seed Carlos Moya continued his season-long domination of Spanish compatriots as he claimed his 14th victory against a countryman in 2004.
His latest victim was Fernando Verdasco, who went down 6-7 (9/11), 6-3, 6-4.

Tim Henman put aside a wait of nearly 12 hours on a drizzly Tuesday, taking just 73 minutes Wednesday to tame Argentine Mariano Zabaleta 6-4, 6-1. The victory puts the fifth seed into a second-round clash with crowd-favourite Gustavo Kuerten of Brazil.
"It was great to finally get onto court. There were beautiful conditions out there today. Neither of us played our best match, but it was good to get the win."
Andy Roddick tosses his racquet in frustration during the second set against Julien Benneteau during the Tennis Masters Canada at the Rexall Center in Toronto, Ontario, Canada
Roger Federer salutes the crowd after defeating Hicham Arazi of Morocco during the Tennis Masters Canada at the Rexall Center in Toronto, Ontario, Canada

NewsLines.HeadLine: A trainer looks at Fernando Verdasco

DataContent.p: A trainer looks after Fernando Verdasco in the second set against Carlos Moya of Spain during the Tennis Masters Canada at the Rexall Center in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Moya won 6-7 (9/11), 6-3, 6-4
